sense.name: an enumerated total number
sense.commentary: COUNT[+quantity][+total][+enumerated][+of_collection] Note: references a number, not the act of determining the number (Sense 2)
sense.examples: The patient's white blood count seems lower than normal. 342 is the final count for people registered for the conference The count to the batter is currently two balls and two strikes. (a recalculated number after each pitch during baseball which represents number of balls and strikes)

sense.name: the act of enumerating or tallying a total
sense.commentary: COUNT[+event][+enumeration][+of_total] Note: implies an agent or actor doing the enumeration
sense.examples: The teacher did a count of hands to see how many students wanted a take-home exam. They did a second count of divers on the boat to make sure no one had been left in the water. The party's only candidate was eliminated after the first count of votes.

sense.name: act of reciting numbers to time something
sense.examples: The dancers had to hold the pose for a count of seven. The boxer did not get up again during the referee's count to ten.

sense.name: a criminal charge against someone
sense.examples: The man was arrested on two counts of assault and battery. Each terrorist will be charged with 200 counts of first-degree murder. They dropped one count of drunk driving against John.

sense.name: an issue or topic for consideration
sense.examples: This program remains vulnerable on a number of counts. On several counts, Bill would make a better CEO than Bob.

sense.name: a European nobleman of equal rank with a British earl
sense.examples: There were many dukes, counts and earls at the palace's grand ball. The dashing Hungarian count bowed and kissed the lady's hand.

sense.name: a measure of the density of woven fabric
sense.examples: The finer the yarn, the greater its count per length. These fine Egyptian cotton sheets have a high thread count.
